intro: Salvia sphacelioides subsp. anaglypha, commonly known as the Sierra Nevada sage, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its erect stem and pairs of opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces showy, two-lipped flowers in shades of blue to purple, which bloom in late summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it well-suited for rock gardens and xeriscaping. Its ornamental value and adaptability make it a popular choice among native plant enthusiasts.
